title.value: Cross-ethnicity/race generalization failure of behavioral prediction from resting-state functional connectivity
title.justification: This title clearly encapsulates the primary research goal of the paper, which is to analyze how well predictive models applied to brain data generalize across different ethnic/racial groups.
title.quote: Cross-ethnicity/race generalization failure of behavioral prediction from resting-state functional connectivity

extractions.description: The paper investigates the ethnic/racial biases in predictive models built to predict behavioral phenotypes from brain functional MRI data. It uses two large U.S. datasets to assess if prediction models trained predominantly on data from white Americans generalize to other ethnic groups, specifically African Americans. The paper highlights that prediction accuracy is generally lower for African Americans, underscoring a need for more representation in training datasets to improve model fairness.

type.justification: The study involves analyzing data from two large datasets to understand the fairness of predictive models across different ethnic/racial groups, constituting an empirical investigation.
type.quote: We used two publicly available large datasets of the U.S. population to ensure that our findings were not specific to a specific age range, scanning process (single versus multisite), and preprocessing strategy.

name.justification: The study focuses on predictive modeling based on brain functional MRI data, which is a prominent topic in neuroscience.
name.quote: In neuroscience, one major line of research aims to predict behavioral phenotype from brain data, in particular using resting-Â­state/task/naturalistic functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI).

name.justification: The research addresses algorithmic biases in machine learning models, specifically their fairness in prediction across different ethnic/racial groups.
name.quote: Algorithmic biases that favor majority populations pose a key challenge to the application of machine learning for precision medicine.

name.justification: The study uses functional MRI data as the core input for predictive modeling.
name.quote: Behavioral predictive models were built using the kernel ridge regression method on resting-state functional connectivity data from fMRI.

name.justification: Kernel Ridge Regression is the primary predictive model used in the study to predict behavioral measures from functional MRI data.
name.quote: Kernel ridge regression models were trained on the entire datasets including all ethnic/racial groups to predict each behavioral measure from RSFC.

is_contributed.justification: Kernel Ridge Regression is a well-known method and not introduced or proposed by this study.
is_contributed.quote: Kernel ridge regression was selected as the main prediction algorithm in this work because it has been shown to be a fast and effective method for predicting phenotypes from fMRI.

is_executed.justification: The model is executed for predicting behavioral measures as described in the study.
is_executed.quote: Kernel ridge regression models were trained on the entire datasets including all ethnic/racial groups to predict each behavioral measure from RSFC.

is_compared.justification: Kernel Ridge Regression is compared to Linear Ridge Regression to validate the findings.
is_compared.quote: The larger prediction error in AA than WA was not algorithm specific, we used linear ridge regression as a complementary method to corroborate the main findings.

referenced_paper_title.value: Deep neural networks and kernel regression achieve comparable accuracies for functional connectivity prediction of behavior and demographics
referenced_paper_title.justification: This reference discusses Kernel Ridge Regression in the context of predicting behavior, similar to this study's application.
referenced_paper_title.quote: Kernel ridge regression was selected as the main prediction algorithm in this work because it has been shown to be a fast and effective method for predicting phenotypes from fMRI (32).

name.justification: HCP is explicitly mentioned as one of the large datasets used for measuring prediction accuracy across ethnic groups.
name.quote: We used two large-scale datasets containing both neuroimaging and behavioral data from the U.S. population: the Human Connectome Project (HCP; N = 948; age, 22 to 37 years).

referenced_paper_title.value: The Human Connectome Project: A data acquisition perspective
referenced_paper_title.justification: The referenced paper provides detailed information about the HCP dataset, which is extensively used in this study for data analysis.
referenced_paper_title.quote: Data were provided by the Human Connectome Project, WU-Minn Consortium (principal investigators: D. V. Essen and K. Ugurbil) funded by the 16 NIH Institutes and Centers that support the NIH Blueprint for Neuroscience Research, and by the McDonnell Center for Systems Neuroscience at Washington University.

name.justification: The ABCD dataset is used as one of the primary data sources for assessing the model's prediction accuracy across ethnic groups.
name.quote: The Human Connectome Project (HCP; N = 948; age, 22 to 37 years) and the Adolescent Brain Cognitive Development (ABCD; N = 5351; age, 9 to 11 years).

referenced_paper_title.value: The ABCD Study: A national longitudinal study of adolescent brain development and child health
referenced_paper_title.justification: This referenced paper provides foundational information about the ABCD dataset, which is heavily utilized in this study.
referenced_paper_title.quote: Data used in the preparation of this article were also obtained from the Adolescent Brain Cognitive Development \(ABCD\) Study \(https://abcdstudy.org\), held in the NIMH Data Archive \(NDA\).
